tracer.paths

Class Path

  • java.lang.Object
    • tracer.paths.Path
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    processing.core.PConstants, Drawable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Arc, Blender, Circle, Composite, CubicBezier, Ellipse, Gesture, InfinitySymbol, Line, Lissajous, MultiPath, MultiShape, Plot, Rect, Rose, Segment, Shape, Superellipse, Supershape, TranslatedPath

    public abstract class Path
extends java.lang.Object
implements Drawable
    A continuous sequence of points in 2D space.

    Usage:
    To get a point on an Path p, use p.trace(u) or p.trace(pt, u) where u is a floating point value between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) and pt is a Point (a coordinate in 2D space).

    p.trace(0) returns a Point at the beginning of the path. p.trace(0.5) returns a Point in the middle of the path. p.trace(1) returns the point at the end of the path. And so on.

    Alternatively, you can use p.trace(pt, u) which, instead of returning a Point, stores the result of the computation in the given pt. This method is more efficient because it doesn't require a new Point to be allocated.

    To display an Path p, use p.display(g) where g is a PGraphics object.
    Author:
    James Morrow [jamesmorrowdesign.com]

      • trace

        public abstract void trace(Point target,
                           float u)
        Given a 1D coordinate, a float, maps the coordinate to a 2D coordinate and stores it in a given Point.

        Maps a given floating point number within [0, 1) to a given Point along the perimeter of the Path.
        Parameters:
        target - The Point in which the result is stored.
        u - A number within [0, 1)

      • trace

        public Point trace(float u)
        A continuous function from real values (floats) to Points.

        Maps a given floating point number within [0, 1) to a Point along the perimeter of the Path.
        Parameters:
        u - A number within [0, 1).
        Returns:
        The resulting point.

        Parameters:
        dx - The number of pixels to shift the path right.
        dy - The number of pixels to shift the path down.

      • getGap

        public abstract float getGap(int i)
        Gives the ith discontinuity in the Path as a 1D coordinate. Gaps should be unique and indexed in ascending order. In other words, this must hold true: gap(i) < gap(i+1) as i varies from 0 to getGapCount()-1. Gives -1 if the index is valid.
        Parameters:
        i - The index
        Returns:
        The ith discontinuity as a value within [0, 1)

      • isGap

        public boolean isGap(float u)
        Indicates whether or not there is a gap exactly at the 1D coordinate u.
        Parameters:
        u - The 1D coordinate.
        Returns:
        True, if there is a gap and false otherwise.
